did.head: DESCRIPTIVE SUMMARY
did.unittitle: Queers for Economic Justice records, circa 2000-2014.
did.physdesc: 13 cubic feet., 4 mapcase folders, 1 rolled poster
Surveys, posters, banners, and records of the organization.
did.repository: Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Cornell University Library
did.abstract: The records of QEJ consist of key documentation of its founding goals and guiding principles, its sources of funding, the involvement of its staff, executive directors, and Board of Directors, its publicity and outreach efforts, and its major projects including the establishment and operation of a shelter for queer people facing homelessness. Together, these files give a detailed look at the ideas, actions, challenges, and successes of this innovative organization devoted to racial, economic, gender, and sexual equality over its dozen years of operation.

bioghist.head: ORGANIZATIONAL HISTORY
bioghist.p: Formed in 2002 in New York City, Queers for Economic Justice (QEJ) was a "progressive non-profit organization committed to promoting economic justice in a context of sexual and gender liberation." As described on its website, its goal was "to challenge and change the systems that create poverty and economic injustice in our communities, and to promote an economic system that embraces sexual and gender diversity." Distinctive among LGBTQI groups at the time in its foregrounding of poverty and class, QEJ introduced different solutions to the national discussion of the queer agenda. On the local level, it spearheaded changes in New York City laws and policies affecting homeless transgender people and gave tangible assistance to the City's queer people in poverty. Its work policies and staff reflected its commitment to being "multi-racial, multi-classed, multi-cultural group of people of diverse marginalized sexual and gender identities, as well as diverse ages, skills, educational levels, backgrounds and abilities."

In 2006, while substantial political effort focused on attaining marriage equality, QEJ brought together twenty-two activists who crafted a report, later signed by hundreds, that pushed for a wider vision. The report, titled Beyond Same-Sex Marriage: A New Strategic Vision For All Our Families and Relationships, became known as the "Beyond Marriage statement." Over time, QEJ published reports on a variety of topics at the intersection of gender, sexuality, and economic justice, offering perspectives on homelessness and housing, economic justice, immigration, drug laws and public health, marriage and other family forms, and welfare. QEJ's major initiatives included community organizing, research and policy development, leadership training, education, outreach, legal aid and advocacy, and community support groups.

Joseph DeFilippis was QEJ's founding executive director. Subsequent leaders were Kenyon Farrow (2009-2011) and Amber Hollibaugh (2011-2014). Jay Toole served as QEJ's founding and only Shelter Director, leading the organization's work relating to housing and homelessness. Among the other LGBTQ, anti-racism, and anti-poverty activists and scholars engaged with the work of QEJ were Ricky Blum Terry Boggis, Ann Cammett, Aine Duggan, Lisa Duggan, Kenyon Farrow, Monroe France, Felix Gardon, Reina Gossett, Richard Kim, Maureen Lane, Ignacio Rivera, Dean Spade, and Jessica Stern.
Due to financial difficulties, QEJ closed in 2014. The organization's projects in the areas of housing and work continue through Jay's House, a shelter non-profit organization in Brooklyn

scopecontent.head: COLLECTION DESCRIPTION
scopecontent.p: The records of QEJ consist of key documentation of its founding goals and guiding principles, its sources of funding, the involvement of its staff, executive directors, and Board of Directors, its publicity and outreach efforts, and its major projects including the establishment and operation of a shelter for queer people facing homelessness. Together, these files give a detailed look at the ideas, actions, challenges, and successes of this innovative organization devoted to racial, economic, gender, and sexual equality over its dozen years of operation.

arrangement.p:

Box 2-3

Series II. Grants and Foundation Files
Box 1-2, 13

Series VI. Welfare Rights and Shelter Director

Series VII. Students, Volunteer, and Intern Program

Series VIII. Publicity

Series IX. Publications, Packets, and General Information

did.unittitle: Series I. Foundation of Organization, Bylaws, and Constitution

scopecontent.p: This series contains the QEJ personnel manual and other items that reveal how the organization operated internally as well as its goals and mission.

did.unittitle: New York City HIV Planning Group
New York Women's Foundation Grantee Meeting
QEJ Contact info, Minutes, Structures (from binder)
QEJ Surveys, OSI, Pride '03, Cause Effective, Banner, Name/Logo (from binder)
Binder, "Raise The Money You Need: Building Your Individual Donor Program"
Series II. Grants and Foundation Files

scopecontent.p: QEJ obtained funding from numerous sources, including the Astraea Lesbian Foundation, Ben and Jerry's, Gill Foundation, Jewish Fund for Justice, New York Community Trust, New York Women's Foundation, Stonewall Foundation, Unitarian Universalists, and the Paul Rapoport Foundation whose records are preserved at Cornell.

did.unittitle: Application for a letter of agreement
New York Women's Foundation Hurricane Sandy Grant Report
Materials on QEJ from Terry Boggis

scopecontent.p: Board agendas and minutes give top-level insight into the plans and operations of an organization. These begin in December 1999 and are fairly complete.

did.unittitle: Board nominees, meeting minutes, agendas, and notes
Facilitator Agenda, site descriptions, LGBT pamphlets and schedules
Packing slips and copies of checks
Personnel files, sign-in sheets, and tax documents[RESTRICTED]
Personnel files, sign-in sheets, and tax documents[RESTRICTED]

scopecontent.p: Budget materials are in this series, along with miscellaneous files that might rightfully belong in other series, including speeches, conferences, and information on programs and an affordable housing rally.

did.unittitle: Budget notes, meeting minutes, tax information
Whitehouse conference on Housing and Astraea forms
Correspondence on blog posts, copies of articles

scopecontent.p:
These files document the core work QEJ did, including sharing their insight and knowledge at Creating Change, the annual activist conference hosted by the National LGBT Task Force. There is good documentation of the annual Amazingly Queer Race for Economic Justice, a âscavenger hunt across the city, in which competing teams will raise funds to combat poverty, homelessness and other urban injustices.â
There are three folders about the working group that wrote Beyond Same-Sex Marriage: A New Strategic Vision For All Our Families and Relationships, and these shed light on how the marriage summit came to be and the behind-the-scenes thinking about it.

did.unittitle: Sheets from a workshop QEJ convened
Creating Change Conference and Class Institute docs

Beyond Same-Sex Marriage planning documents for the summit and talking points about the release of the statement
Social Security and Tax Cuts Forum
Rockefeller Drug Law/Queer Policy Work/ Cole P.
State of the Homeless and miscellaneous

scopecontent.p: A folder of photographs and the files of shelter director Jay Toole are included in the administrative records of QEJâs Shelter project.

Series VII. Students, Volunteer, and Intern Program

scopecontent.p: Among the job descriptions and reports about students, volunteers, and interns are information about a QEJ transgender meeting, and notes from a 1999 QEJ network meeting, prior to QEJâs founding.

did.unittitle: First public work and meeting for QEJ network

scopecontent.p:
The brochures, fliers, booklets, and posters designed to share information about the Shelter Safety Welfare Warriors, the Amazingly Queer Race for Economic Justice, and other projects, as well as articles about QEJ and one folder on QEJâs history. The folder âWhy Welfare Reform is a Queer Issueâ includes materials from 1996-1999, prior to QEJâs founding.
Among the posters are:âMiss Jay Toole: Building for Social Justice,â "No Human is Illegal," "Sex Worker Visions," "End Eviction Orders!" "Welfare Made a Difference," handmade signs and posters, and a plastic QEJ sign.

did.unittitle: Amazingly Queer Race planning book (from binder)

Handmade signs and posters remembering individuals who had died, and messages including "Silence = Death" "Queer the Mind" and "Don't Deny It, Stonewall was a Riot."
